text: Which shortcut opens the Task Manager directly in Windows?
explanation: Ctrl + Shift + Esc opens Task Manager directly, bypassing the Windows Security screen.

text: Which built-in command displays the IP configuration of a Windows machine?
explanation: The ipconfig command shows IP, subnet, and gateway information for all interfaces.

text: What is the default file system used by modern versions of Windows?
explanation: NTFS is the default file system used for Windows OS drives.

text: Which tool allows you to view and manage system event logs?
explanation: Event Viewer is the MMC snap-in used to review system and application logs.

text: Which Windows utility allows you to manage local user accounts?
explanation: Computer Management includes the Local Users and Groups snap-in.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet lists all running services?
explanation: Get-Service returns all system services with their current state.

text: Which command stops a service named 'Spooler'?
explanation: Stop-Service Spooler stops the Print Spooler service.

text: What is the purpose of the 'Import-Module' cmdlet?

choices.text: Installs a PowerShell module from the gallery
Loads a module into the current session

explanation: Import-Module loads a module so its cmdlets are available for use in the current session.

text: Which cmdlet displays the last errors in PowerShell?
explanation: The automatic variable $Error contains an array of the most recent error objects.

text: Which PowerShell command enables remote management via WinRM?
explanation: Enable-PSRemoting configures the WinRM service and firewall to allow remote PowerShell sessions.

text: Select all valid methods to execute a PowerShell script remotely.
explanation: Remote PowerShell sessions can use Invoke-Command, Enter-PSSession, or persistent sessions via New-PSSession.

text: Which role provides centralized authentication for Windows networks?
explanation: Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) handles authentication and domain management.

text: Which command-line tool adds a computer to a domain?
explanation: netdom join allows joining a computer to a domain from the command line.

text: Which DNS record type maps a domain name to an IPv4 address?
explanation: An A (Address) record maps a hostname to an IPv4 address.

text: Which Windows Server role is responsible for assigning IP addresses automatically?
explanation: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) automatically assigns IP addresses and configurations to clients.

text: Select all FSMO (Flexible Single Master Operations) roles in Active Directory.
explanation: FSMO roles include Schema Master, Domain Naming Master, RID Master, PDC Emulator, and Infrastructure Master.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet creates a new Active Directory user account?
explanation: New-ADUser creates a new user object in Active Directory.

text: Which tool helps monitor replication status between domain controllers?
explanation: repadmin is used to check replication health and force synchronization between DCs.

text: What port is used by LDAP for unencrypted communication?
explanation: LDAP uses TCP port 389 by default; LDAPS (secure) uses 636.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlets can query Active Directory objects?
explanation: Get-ADUser, Get-ADComputer, and Get-ADGroup are all part of the ActiveDirectory module.

text: Which tool can enforce password complexity and account lockout policies?
explanation: Local Security Policy (secpol.msc) enforces account and password policies.

text: Which Windows feature isolates system processes to protect against kernel-level malware?
explanation: VBS uses hardware virtualization to isolate critical system processes.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet can be used to audit file permissions recursively?
explanation: Get-Acl retrieves Access Control Lists for files and directories.

text: Which command-line tool can verify domain controller replication and diagnose AD issues?
explanation: dcdiag analyzes the state of domain controllers and reports AD health issues.

text: Which AD object type represents network resources such as printers or computers?
explanation: Computer objects represent machines joined to the domain.

text: Which protocol does Active Directory use for authentication?
explanation: Kerberos is the primary authentication protocol used by Active Directory since Windows 2000.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet retrieves domain controller information from Active Directory?
explanation: Get-ADDomainController lists domain controllers and their properties in the domain.

text: Which of the following are Active Directory database and log file names by default?
explanation: The AD database is stored in ntds.dit, and transaction logs use edb.log files.

text: Where is the SYSVOL folder replicated between domain controllers?
explanation: SYSVOL contains logon scripts and group policy templates, replicated via DFS-R between domain controllers.

text: Which MMC snap-in is used to manage Group Policy Objects in a domain?
explanation: The Group Policy Management Console (gpmc.msc) manages GPOs across the domain.

text: Which command refreshes Group Policy settings on a client immediately?
explanation: gpupdate /force forces immediate application of all Group Policies.

text: In which order are Group Policies applied?
explanation: Policies apply in the order: Local, Site, Domain, then Organizational Unit (LSDOU).

text: What is the default refresh interval for Group Policy on domain-joined computers?
explanation: Group Policy refreshes every 90 minutes with a random offset of 0–30 minutes.

text: Which Group Policy tools can display Resultant Set of Policy (RSoP) data?
explanation: gpresult, RSoP.msc, and the Group Policy Results Wizard can show which GPOs apply to a user or computer.

text: Which command can test DNS name resolution on a Windows system?
explanation: nslookup queries DNS servers to verify name resolution.

text: Which command clears the DNS cache on a Windows client?
explanation: ipconfig /flushdns clears the local DNS resolver cache.

text: Which tool traces the route packets take to a remote host?
explanation: tracert shows each hop between the source and destination host.

text: What does the command 'netsh int ip reset' do?
explanation: netsh int ip reset resets TCP/IP configuration back to factory defaults.

text: Select all commands useful for diagnosing DHCP-related issues.
explanation: ipconfig /release and /renew test client-side DHCP, while Get-DhcpServerv4Scope shows server scopes.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet retrieves information about network adapters?
explanation: Get-NetAdapter provides adapter names, MAC addresses, and statuses.

text: What is the default lease duration for DHCP on a Windows Server?
explanation: Windows DHCP server sets a default lease time of 8 days (7 days visible to users).

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet allows you to schedule recurring tasks directly in PowerShell?
explanation: Register-ScheduledTask creates and registers a scheduled task for execution based on triggers.

text: What is the purpose of PowerShell profiles (e.g., $PROFILE)?

choices.text: They store user credentials for scripts
They define startup configuration, aliases, and functions

explanation: $PROFILE files let you customize the PowerShell environment by defining functions, variables, and aliases at startup.

text: Which features make PowerShell ideal for automation?
explanation: PowerShell automation is powerful due to object-based pipelines, .NET integration, and cross-platform scripting in PowerShell 7+.

text: What does the 'Set-ExecutionPolicy RemoteSigned' command do?

choices.text: Allows only digitally signed scripts to run
Allows local scripts to run and requires signatures for remote ones
Allows all scripts to run without restriction

explanation: RemoteSigned allows local scripts to run freely but requires signatures for scripts downloaded from the Internet.

text: Which cmdlet securely stores credentials for use in PowerShell automation?
explanation: Get-Credential securely prompts for credentials and stores them as PSCredential objects.

text: Which parameter allows a PowerShell function to accept pipeline input?
explanation: Parameters marked with ValueFromPipeline accept input from PowerShell pipelines.

text: Which Windows feature helps prevent unauthorized code from running in kernel mode?
explanation: Secure Boot verifies kernel and bootloader integrity to prevent rootkits.

text: Which policy can restrict which applications users can run?
explanation: WDAC (and older AppLocker) enforce allow/block rules for executables and scripts.

text: Which tool encrypts entire Windows drives, including system drives?
explanation: BitLocker encrypts entire drives and integrates with TPM for key protection.

text: Select all Windows Defender features that support system hardening.
explanation: All listed features are part of Windows Defender's security hardening suite.

text: Which Windows security feature stores secrets in a virtualized, isolated environment?
explanation: Credential Guard isolates and protects LSASS secrets using virtualization-based security.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet enables BitLocker encryption on a drive?
explanation: Enable-BitLocker activates BitLocker on a volume and can save recovery keys.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet audits system update compliance via Windows Update?
explanation: Get-HotFix lists all installed Windows updates for compliance verification.

text: Select all practices recommended for securing PowerShell in enterprise environments.
explanation: Script block logging, execution policy control, and Constrained Language Mode help mitigate script-based attacks.

text: What is the purpose of the 'Secure Boot' feature in UEFI firmware?

choices.text: It verifies signed bootloaders to prevent tampering

explanation: Secure Boot validates that only trusted, signed bootloaders and OS components are loaded.

text: Which log file stores Windows Defender Antivirus detections?

choices.text: Event Viewer → Applications and Services Logs → Microsoft → Windows → Windows Defender → Operational

explanation: Defender events are stored in the Windows Event Viewer under the Windows Defender Operational log.

text: Which Windows tool provides real-time CPU, memory, and disk usage statistics?
explanation: Task Manager gives a real-time summary of CPU, memory, disk, and network usage.

text: Which Windows utility allows you to create long-term performance counters for analysis?
explanation: Performance Monitor allows administrators to create and record data collector sets for detailed performance analysis.

text: Which tool provides a graphical overview of system stability and problem history?
explanation: Reliability Monitor visualizes hardware and software failures to help identify system stability issues.

text: Which performance counters are most useful for identifying disk bottlenecks?
explanation: Disk Queue Length, Transfers/sec, and Avg. Disk sec/Transfer indicate disk performance and latency.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet retrieves performance counter data?
explanation: Get-Counter retrieves real-time performance data from local or remote systems.

text: Which command opens the System Configuration utility (MSConfig)?
explanation: MSConfig allows you to control startup processes and boot options for troubleshooting.

text: What is the recommended paging file size on a Windows Server with 16 GB RAM?
explanation: A paging file of about 1.5× RAM is a common baseline; tuning depends on workload.

text: Which Windows Server feature allows live migration of virtual machines?
explanation: Hyper-V Live Migration transfers running virtual machines between hosts without downtime.

text: Select all common causes of high CPU usage in Windows Servers.
explanation: High CPU can result from update scans, inefficient code, or misconfigured workloads like databases.

text: Which Windows feature automatically tunes power and performance settings for servers?
explanation: Dynamic Optimization in Windows Server and Hyper-V adjusts workloads for best performance and efficiency.

text: Which tool creates system state backups in Windows Server?
explanation: wbadmin performs command-line backups including system state, useful for AD and OS recovery.

text: Where does Windows Server store Active Directory backups by default?
explanation: wbadmin lets you specify the backup destination; it does not store AD backups in system folders.

text: Which PowerShell command can export all DHCP settings for disaster recovery?
explanation: Export-DhcpServer backs up DHCP scope and lease data for import on recovery.

text: Which are valid steps in a bare-metal restore of a Windows Server?

choices.text: Select system image from backup storage

explanation: Bare-metal recovery uses installation media and wbadmin to restore from a saved system image.

text: Which Windows Server feature provides automatic failover between multiple nodes?
explanation: Failover Clustering provides high availability by automatically switching to healthy nodes during failures.

text: Which role in Windows Server provides automatic IP address assignment to clients?
explanation: The DHCP Server role automatically assigns IP addresses and configuration parameters to network clients.

text: Which record type in DNS maps a hostname to an IPv6 address?
explanation: An AAAA (quad-A) record maps a hostname to an IPv6 address.

text: Which command can clear the local DNS resolver cache in Windows?
explanation: ipconfig /flushdns clears the local DNS cache to force re-resolution of domain names.

text: What is the default port used for DNS queries?
explanation: DNS uses port 53 over UDP for standard queries and TCP for zone transfers.

text: Select all valid DHCP lease states.
explanation: DHCP leases can be Active, Expired, or Declined if conflicts are detected.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet exports DHCP configuration for backup?
explanation: Export-DhcpServer saves DHCP configuration and leases for import on another server.

text: Which Windows Server feature allows central management of IP address spaces across multiple networks?
explanation: IPAM provides centralized monitoring and management of IP address ranges, DNS, and DHCP servers.

text: Which DNS record type maps an IP address to a hostname (reverse lookup)?
explanation: PTR records are used for reverse DNS lookups (IP to hostname resolution).

text: Select all Windows Server technologies that support fault tolerance.
explanation: All these features improve availability: clustering, DFS replication, NIC teaming, and Hyper-V Replica.

text: Which Windows Server feature enables file sharing across multiple servers with fault tolerance?
explanation: DFS allows shared folders to be replicated and accessed from multiple servers under a unified namespace.

text: Which command checks the replication health of DFS?
explanation: The dfsrdiag tool checks replication state, backlog, and partner sync health for DFS.

text: What port does DHCP use for client requests?
explanation: DHCP uses UDP port 67 for server and 68 for client communications.

text: Select all features supported by IPAM (IP Address Management).
explanation: IPAM manages IP address tracking, DHCP scope monitoring, and DNS zone administration.

text: What is the role of WINS in older Windows networks?

choices.text: Resolves NetBIOS names to IP addresses

explanation: WINS (Windows Internet Name Service) resolves NetBIOS names, primarily used before DNS adoption.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet retrieves cluster node information in a failover cluster?
explanation: Get-ClusterNode returns information about all nodes in a failover cluster.

text: Which Windows feature enables the creation and management of virtual machines?
explanation: Hyper-V is Microsoft’s native hypervisor built into Windows Server and some editions of Windows 10/11.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet creates a new virtual machine in Hyper-V?
explanation: New-VM creates a new virtual machine with defined parameters such as name, memory, and VHD path.

text: Which file extension is used by Hyper-V for virtual hard disks?
explanation: Hyper-V uses VHDX files for virtual disks, offering larger capacity and better resilience than older VHD files.

text: Select all technologies that support live migration of VMs in Windows Server.
explanation: Hyper-V supports Live Migration (clustered), Shared-Nothing Migration, and Storage Migration for moving running VMs.

text: Which Hyper-V feature allows creating checkpoints to save the state of a VM?
explanation: Checkpoints capture the state, data, and configuration of a VM for later restoration.

text: Which tool manages disks and volumes on Windows servers?
explanation: Disk Management (diskmgmt.msc) allows administrators to create, extend, and format volumes.

text: Which file system is optimized for large-scale data and resilient storage on Windows Server?
explanation: ReFS (Resilient File System) provides better integrity, scalability, and fault tolerance for large data volumes.

text: Which Windows Server feature combines multiple disks into a fault-tolerant pool?
explanation: Storage Spaces aggregates physical disks into a virtual pool supporting mirroring, parity, and resiliency.

text: Which components are part of a Storage Spaces Direct (S2D) deployment?
explanation: S2D uses local drives in clustered nodes with Cluster Shared Volumes and Failover Clustering for resiliency.

text: Which PowerShell cmdlet creates a new virtual hard disk file?
explanation: New-VHD creates a virtual disk (.vhd or .vhdx) that can be attached to VMs.

text: Which service enables connecting on-premises Windows Servers to Azure for centralized management?
explanation: Azure Arc brings hybrid management and policy control for on-premises and multi-cloud Windows servers.

text: Which tool synchronizes on-premises Active Directory with Azure AD?
explanation: Azure AD Connect (ADSync) synchronizes local directory objects to Azure AD for hybrid identity.

text: Select all technologies used for hybrid disaster recovery in Azure.
explanation: Azure Backup and Site Recovery provide off-site data protection and VM replication to Azure.

text: Which Azure service provides unified monitoring for Windows Servers and VMs?
explanation: Azure Monitor aggregates performance, log, and alert data across on-premises and cloud systems.

text: Which Windows Server feature integrates with Azure for cloud-based backup management?
explanation: Azure Backup Agent connects Windows Servers directly to Azure Recovery Services Vault for cloud-based backups.
